instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.P3V3S4_EN: What is P3V3S4_EN? P3V3S4_EN is a signal that enables the PP3V3_S4 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
Experts,

I hit a wall, and could use your insights on how to get moving.

<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
70mA when in case, 20mA when not. No fan spin.
Unit is in S3AC mode, per chart on schematic p.64 using [I]<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>[/I], [I]<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>[/I][ABLE], and [I]<SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL>[/I]

Symptoms: 
1. Every [I]rareth [/I]time, system comes up. shows battery as dead (big red battery icon), not charging.
All other times (virtually all), does not come up.
2. One pin pair on the magsafe blew out-both sides black, some metal from the tip of the PS plug gone. Doesn't seem to have made a difference, except the 'other' pin on the PS plug isn't pogo any more (stuck).

pic of PS plug: 

[ATTACH type="full" width="177px"]60419[/ATTACH]

...and the LB:

[ATTACH type="full" width="231px"]60420[/ATTACH]

Steps:

All "G3 Hot" (Always-Present) rails OK.
Starting on 5v:
1. OK = <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>
2. 0v = <SIGNAL>PP5_S5_FET</SIGNAL> mostly 0V, sometimes 5V after PS on a while!? ([I]@<CHIP>U8060</CHIP> pin 5/6[/I])
3. <CHIP>U8060</CHIP>:
pin 1/3: 5v ([I]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_P5VS5FET</SIGNAL> [/I][[I]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>[/I]])
pin 2: 0v ([I]<SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> [/I]in)
4. Tracing <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> tp p.64 at <CAPACITOR>C8192</CAPACITOR> = 0v
5. Tracing back to <CHIP>U8170</CHIP>:
pin 6: 3.3v [I]irrelevant[/I] (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> = power for OR gate 8170 ([I]NOSTUFF[/I]))
pin 2: 0v ([I]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>[/I]) per chart on same page, it is only HIGH when in modes S3, S3AC, and S0. This pin Low makes [I]<SIGNAL>P3V3S4_EN</SIGNAL>[/I] low as well.
How to make <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> go Hi?
Pulled L by <RESISTOR>R1460</RESISTOR> (p.13), Pulled H by <CHIP>U0500</CHIP> (Broadwell) pin AP5 ([I]<SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL>*[/I]) on same page.

So, I'm stuck at the Broadwell :-(
I was hoping to find out why we were stuck in S5 (even though p.64 table says in S3AC...)

TIA!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

You have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present, but PCH requires more signals, before starting power on sequence.
Post voltage for <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.

Be sure to use original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
Thanks [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER]. You guys are great. 

The first 3 signals were all 3.3V, and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> was 0V, but that makes sense as the LB is not in the case. Checked the MOSFET "BATLOW# ISOLATION", nothing on any pin. 
Gate signal comes from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TBT</SIGNAL>, and <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> seems to be off, with both ENables (EN & HVEN) at 0V, and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TBTAPWRSW</SIGNAL> at 3.3V. 
The magsafe LED goes from green to orange, and stays there. 
The SSD is cool, like everything else on it.
Am I right that the LB is stuck at S5?
It's been a week, and it stinks that I have no distinct signal symptom to chase yet... 

Thanks again!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
PCH requires high level on <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> to start power on sequence.

"Be sure to use original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger."
???

Be aware of wrong assumptions; don't waste time with thunderbolt area.
Board MUST turn on alone on the desk, even without LIO flex connected; only needs LIO power cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
Thanks [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] ! 
I think I made progress. But first:
"PCH requires high level on <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> to start power on sequence. "
Just by the name of the signal, does this mean a battery that is not 0% is required to boot? I must not understand the signal.

re: Progress:
0. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A p. 75/sheet 58.
1. I replaced <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>.
2. When checking for solder bridges after, I had a short between pins 23 (VIN/[B]<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER3V3_ISNS</SIGNAL>[/B])& 24 (DRVH/[B]P3V3S5[/B]/[B]<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_TG</SIGNAL>[/B]). Great! Too much solder...
3. I pulled the new one off, and [I]the short was still there[/I]!
4. Here is the relationship between the 2 pins:

[ATTACH type="full"]60421[/ATTACH]

...and here is the MOSFET (<TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>/FDMS3602S), just off to the right of the above image:

[ATTACH type="full"]60422[/ATTACH]
Should the Gate & Drain on this dual N-Channel be shorted? My instinct says [I]no[/I]. And because the signal to pin 24 takes a direct path to/from the MOSFET Gate, there are no alternate signal paths to short indicated. With <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> removed, and on the pins of the MOSFET directly, Gate & Drain are shorted.

Thoughts?

TIA!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
Replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>.

Be aware, do not power on the board without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, if <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>/60 are soldered!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
Thanks [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER]! I screwed up and removed <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, and cleaned/tinned the pins-[I]all with the power on[/I].
Ordering dual MOSFETs for both sides now. It sounds like I shorted out <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> (if this is how they fail).
Dohh!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
Well, all MOSFETs replaced, and now I have a very strange symptom-once again on the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. First a pic for reference:

[ATTACH type="full"]60542[/ATTACH]
This is from page 54 of the schematic for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A.

At pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> I have good voltage ~13v.
At pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> I have nothing(!).
So <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> has nothing on pin 3 (ACIN).

Fix:
Bad trace (open) from pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> to pin 3 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; repaired with jumper.

Tried: 
Replaced 7110 (though it tested OK at 68kΩ.
Removed <CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR>-no change.
Pin 3 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is just under 100Ω to ground.
<RESISTOR>R7111</RESISTOR> tested at 2.4kΩ in-circuit.
Re-flowed <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, no adjacent pin shorts.


Ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
"Pin 3 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is just under 100Ω to ground."
Replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
[USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] I just lifted it, and pin 3 is 0Ω to the pad (pin 29), but without a schematic, I don't know why it isn't also grounded to pin 22 ("GND")...

Right before I lifted it, I measured the full 16v across <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR>, which I should have done yesterday. That told the story.

Really appreciate your confirmation!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message:
I was checking for pin shorts before powering up, and well, I must have had too much solder on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pins 22, 23, 24, because they were all shorted together. 

I sucked out enough without lifting to unshort pin 24 (<SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL>), but pins 22 (GND) and pin 23 (<SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL>) remain shorted together...

[ATTACH type="full"]60544[/ATTACH]

From the above, the only way I see pad 22 short to pad 23 is via <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>. 
When I checked, <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> pins 10 to 5/6/7 were shorted (MOSFET saturated). 
As <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is an Nch, I shorted the gate (pin 8) to 5/6/7 (GND), and checked to verify pin 10 to pins 5/6/7-BUT THE SHORT REMAINS (3.4Ω)!
...
Lifting <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is hairy as L7130 is right next to it ([I]already replaced it per above direction[/I]), but I guess I have to, unless you guys see another way for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 23 to have 3.4Ω to ground?
...
Lifted <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, and pins 5/6/7 are 0Ω (as expected)...
But pin 10 (<SIGNAL>CHGR_PASE</SIGNAL>) is 3.1Ω to GND! 
So <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> pin 10 isn't getting to GND via the MOSFET... 
...
For reference, the shorted (3.1Ω to GND) pin/output becomes <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (same schematic page, on right).
Now I'm chasing a shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, it seems!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message: Lift F7140 and check which side the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No ACIN on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 3...
threads.message: Wrap-up. I sent this board to a shop in NYC, and there are too many layer shorts on the board to fix it. The power surge made even all the above not enough. I bought another LB, and have started a new thread about that board... Many thanks for those who helped all those hours I spent on that POS...
